item.title: U.S. Treasury Chief Hints at Argentina Financial Rescue
item.description: Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said the Trump administration is looking at options to provide Argentina a financial lifeline as the country struggles to overhaul its economy.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Dubé

item.title: In Historic Shift, U.K., Australia and Canada Recognize a Palestinian State
item.description: France and several more countries are expected to follow suit Monday in an effort to pressure Israel to stop its war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Anat Peled

item.title: Kim Jong Un’s Proposition to Trump: Let’s Talk—but Not About Nukes
item.description: The North Korean leader’s offer to sit down with the president challenges a long-held U.S. policy of no dialogue unless disarmament is on the table.
item.dc:creator: Dasl Yoon

item.title: The World Sees Hope for a Two-State Solution. Israelis and Palestinians See None.
item.description: International frustration with Israel is leading to a push to revive the two-state solution. This could be its last chance.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Walker

item.title: Opinion | Are Mexican Politicians Running Cartels?
item.description: A former government official is arrested on charges of operating a criminal network.
item.dc:creator: Mary Anastasia O’Grady

item.title: Opinion | Is There a Manstein in Kyiv?
item.description: By emulating the general’s methods, Ukrainians might finally convince Vladimir Putin that he can’t win this war.

item.title: Ukraine’s Supply Runs Turn to Nightmares as Drones Menace Roads Far Beyond the Front
item.description: In eastern Ukraine, new Russian drone tactics have made supply roads nearly as dangerous as the trenches.
item.dc:creator: Ian Lovett

item.title: The Daring Caper of a Faithful Tibetan Who Outfoxed China
item.description: He escaped from police and crossed thousands of miles of wilderness on a decadelong odyssey toward freedom.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Citrin-Safadi

item.title: Trump’s U.N. Speech to Tout Achievements at a Place Where He Has Given Up Influence
item.description: The U.S. has left ambassador posts unfilled for months, aligned with Russia on key votes and trimmed its contribution to the global body’s budget,
item.dc:creator: Alexander Ward

item.title: NATO Planes Intercept Russian Jet Fighters Over Estonia
item.description: The incident caused the tiny Baltic state to call for formal consultations with members of the Western alliance.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: Gaza City’s Christians, Defying Israel, Stay in Their Churches
item.description: Many Christians in Gaza City have decided to lean on their faith as Israel moves into the ground phase of its operation.
item.dc:creator: Suha Ma’ayeh

item.title: One of Globalization’s Biggest Winners Navigates a Less Predictable World
item.description: Singapore’s prime minister has deepened the city-state’s ties with other nations as the U.S. rethinks trade and security.
item.dc:creator: Gordon Fairclough

item.title: Trump Says U.S. and China Approve TikTok Deal After Call With Xi
item.description: The preliminary agreement would involve a group of investors taking control of TikTok’s U.S. operations, though many details still need to be worked out.
item.dc:creator: Lingling Wei

item.title: Opinion | Iran Loses ‘Snap-Back’ Vote in a Landslide
item.description: Even the U.N. Security Council is fed up with Tehran’s nuclear stalling.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | What Does Trump Want in Venezuela?
item.description: Deposing Maduro is in the U.S. interest, and America should help if Venezuelans lead..
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Under Trump Pressure, EU Proposes Going After Chinese Companies Buying Russia Oil
item.description: The bloc unveiled measures that would seek to squeeze Russia, but wouldn’t fully meet demands by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Georgi Kantchev

item.title: Opinion | Europe Tries to Export Censorship to America
item.description: The Digital Services Act may compel social-media platforms to suppress speech in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Megan K. Jacobson

item.title: U.S. Plans $6 Billion in New Arms Sales to Israel
item.description: The Trump administration is seeking congressional approval for the sales, moving forward despite Israel’s recent missile strike on Hamas in Qatar.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Gramer

item.title: Putin In No Mood to Negotiate, U.K. Spy Chief Says
item.description: In a veiled message to President Trump, the departing head of MI6 warned that the Russian president has no intention of stopping his war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: Netanyahu Responds to International Pressure With a Playbook He Knows: Defiance
item.description: The Israeli leader stunned markets when he suggested the country should lean into its growing international isolation over the war in Gaza and become self-reliant.
item.dc:creator: Shayndi Raice

item.title: Marilyn Hagerty, Whose Column on Olive Garden Went Viral in 2012, Dies at 99
item.description: It was a simpler time online, her son recalls—and his no-nonsense mother broke through the noise for all the right reasons
item.dc:creator: James R. Hagerty

item.title: Why Asia’s Gen Z Is Angry With Its Leaders
item.description: The perceived privileges enjoyed by political elites have sparked a wave of protests across Asia, where a large generation of young people is feeling deprived of economic opportunities.
item.dc:creator: Krishna Pokharel

item.title: Israel’s Attack Blew Up Qatar’s Bet on Being Friends With Everyone
item.description: The attack on Hamas leaders in the U.S. ally’s capital is pressuring Doha’s strategy of being a back channel to adversaries while showering money on friends.
item.dc:creator: Anat Peled

item.title: Trump’s Trade War Split Canada and Mexico. Now They Want a United Front.
item.description: America’s top two trading partners are seeking a strategic partnership ahead of negotiations with the U.S. over tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Vipal Monga

item.title: Opinion | Israeli Lasers and American Defense
item.description: The Iron Beam can intercept drones and other threats of our age.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Saudi Arabia Seeks New Security Alliances as Trust in U.S. Erodes
item.description: The kingdom signed a new defense pact with Pakistan a week after Israel carried out a missile attack targeting Hamas political officials in Qatar, another key U.S. Arab Gulf partner.
item.dc:creator: Omar Abdel-Baqui

item.title: Protesters in France Push Back on Efforts to Rein In Spending
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of people poured into the streets across France, piling pressure on the president and his newly appointed prime minister to abandon any austerity measures.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Meichtry

item.title: Trump, Starmer Paper Over Cracks Amid Royal Pageantry
item.description: The two leaders projected unity despite differences over Palestinian statehood, immigration and energy policy.
item.dc:creator: Tarini Parti

item.title: Why Putin Can’t Afford to Let Ukraine Prosper
item.description: A free and thriving Ukraine would make it undeniable that Putin’s rule has been an economic disaster for Russia.
item.dc:creator: Michael Tory

item.title: China Hardens Military Stance Against U.S. With Nuclear Weapons and Tough Talk
item.description: Beijing has put its firepower on display in recent weeks, including by parading its nuclear weapons, while also hardening its rhetoric on thorny issues.
item.dc:creator: Brian Spegele

item.title: Why Trump Privately Fumes About Netanyahu but Gives Him Free Rein
item.description: The president’s frustration boiled over last week hours after Israel attacked Hamas negotiators in Qatar, an operation that threatened to derail fragile peace talks.
item.dc:creator: Dov Lieber

item.title: A Politician’s Secret Power: He’ll Say Anything for $95
item.description: Britain’s Nigel Farage is winning young fans partly by selling short, sometimes inappropriate video greetings he probably doesn’t understand.
item.dc:creator: James Hookway

item.title: In Gaza City, Israel Looks for a Way to Kill Hamas but Not Its Hostages
item.description: The risk is that the Israeli military can’t do both, and security services say they are moving troops into Gaza City cautiously because of the danger.
item.dc:creator: Dov Lieber

item.title: How Britain’s Keir Starmer Became Europe’s Soft-Spoken Trump Whisperer
item.description: The U.K. prime minister’s surprising rapport with the U.S. president offers a model other European leaders hope to emulate.
item.dc:creator: Max Colchester

item.title: Exxon Mobil to Halt European Recycling Plant Investments
item.description: The company is halting more than $100 million in planned investments for two European chemical recycling projects because of concerns over new rules that the company says will undermine the projects’ business case.
item.dc:creator: Kim Mackrael

item.title: Senior Wells Fargo Banker Returns From China After Exit Ban
item.description: The banker’s return to the U.S. comes amid negotiations between Washington and Beijing on trade and the future of TikTok.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Feng

item.title: Alexei Navalny’s Wife Says There Is Fresh Evidence He Was Poisoned
item.description: Yulia Navalnaya said tests in two separate laboratories prove the former presidential candidate and Russian President Vladimir Putin’s main opponent was killed.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Luxmoore

item.title: A Visual Guide to Trump’s State Visit to the U.K.
item.description: The U.S. president is being granted one of the most elaborate state visits as Britain looks to cement its diplomatic ties with America.
item.dc:creator: Elizaveta Galkina

item.title: How the British Flag Became a Flashpoint in a New Culture War
item.description: A flag-flying campaign has morphed into a broader statement against a rise in immigration and sparked a debate on what the flags really mean.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Dangoor

item.title: America Loves Cocaine Again—Mexico’s New Drug King Cashes In
item.description: The Trump administration’s war on fentanyl created an opening for ‘El Señor Mencho’ to smuggle cocaine into the U.S. by the ton.
item.dc:creator: Santiago Pérez

item.title: Russia Hosts Surprise Guests at Its Wargames: U.S. Military Officers
item.description: The invitation came as President Trump is working to end the war in Ukraine and repair ties with Moscow.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: Canadian Transport Minister Freeland Stepping Down, Set to Take on Role as Representative to Ukraine
item.description: Freeland has been invited by Prime Minister Mark Carney to take on the role as Canada’s new special representative for the reconstruction of Ukraine in addition to her position as a member of parliament.
item.dc:creator: Robb M. Stewart

item.title: U.S. Strikes Second Alleged Drug Boat From Venezuela, Trump Says
item.description: The attack killed three people and follows one carried out by U.S. forces earlier this month against a vessel allegedly transporting narcotics.
item.dc:creator: Michael R. Gordon

item.title: China’s Message on Nvidia: We Have Leverage Too
item.description: With the TikTok deal getting closer, Beijing signals it wants a further deal over U.S. technology.
item.dc:creator: Raffaele Huang

item.title: Robert Redford, Award-Winning Actor, Director, Dies at 89
item.description: The long bankable Hollywood movie star also was an advocate for independent film and a force behind the Sundance Film Festival.
item.dc:creator: Chris Kornelis

item.title: South Korea Probes Allegations of Human-Rights Violations Tied to Hyundai Raid
item.description: Seoul is looking at the U.S.’s treatment of Korean citizens inside a detention center, and whether any of them was unfairly arrested.
item.dc:creator: Jiyoung Sohn

item.title: King Charles Rolls Out the Red Carpet to Woo Trump
item.description: With its military and economic power waning, Britain is leaning on its monarchy to keep the Trump administration sweet on the U.K.
item.dc:creator: Tarini Parti

item.title: Modi’s Strategy for Mending Ties With Trump: a Stiff Upper Lip
item.description: India’s prime minister has maintained a stoic silence in the face of sharp comments from Trump, while signaling he is eager to stay friends.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Gramer

item.title: Argentine President Milei Calls His Sister ‘the Boss.’ Now She’s a Liability.
item.description: An election loss and bribery allegations have put a spotlight on Karina Milei and her influence on her older brother.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Dubé

item.title: Nepal Gets First Female Leader After Protest Turmoil
item.description: Sushila Karki, who was the country’s first female chief justice, will be the head of a caretaker government.
item.dc:creator: Krishna Pokharel

item.title: Confusion, Anger, Relief: Korean Engineer Tells of Week in U.S. ICE Detention
item.description: More than 300 employees at a Hyundai battery plant returned home after being detained in a Georgia immigration raid.
item.dc:creator: Dasl Yoon

item.title: The American Farmers China Is Using as a Trade-War Bargaining Chip
item.description: Weeks before the harvest, China has ordered no soybeans from the U.S.—as Beijing snubs products to gain an edge.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Thomas

item.title: U.S.-China Rivalry Sparks a Submarine Arms Race
item.description: Beijing’s fleet is getting quieter and more lethal, while Washington leads in tech but lags in production.
item.dc:creator: Roque Ruiz

item.title: Kenya Uses U.S.-Funded Antiterrorism Courts for Political Crackdown
item.description: Young people who took to the streets to protest corruption and poor job prospects could face decades in maximum-security prison under a set of laws set up to combat al Qaeda.
item.dc:creator: Caroline Kimeu

item.title: This Is the World’s Biggest Animal Migration—and Few Outsiders Have Seen It
item.description: Six million antelope storm through a pocket of Africa that’s nearly impossible to get to, but the Journal caught them on camera. “The entire planet should be amazed that this exists.”
item.dc:creator: Annie Ng

item.title: U.N. Accuses Rwanda-Backed Rebels of Slaughtering Children, Other Civilians in Congo
item.description: M23 rebels in the Democratic Republic of Congo committed what might have been war crimes and crimes against humanity, raping women and executing children and other civilians, the United Nations said.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bariyo

item.title: Putin Says Russia Will Strike Any Western Troops in Ukraine
item.description: The Russian leader’s comments came a day after European and U.S. officials met in Paris to discuss security guarantees for Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Luxmoore

item.title: He Jokes About Trump and Invading Kenya—and May Be Uganda’s Next President
item.description: Muhoozi Kainerugaba, son of the longtime ruler, oversees a key U.S. military partner while boasting about torture and threatening to arrest members of parliament.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Phillips

item.title: Russia, China Close In on Pipeline Deal, Leaving Beijing With the Upper Hand
item.description: The two countries advanced plans for the long-delayed pipeline to funnel Russian fuel to China but left core terms unresolved, a sign of Beijing’s growing leverage.
item.dc:creator: Georgi Kantchev

item.title: The Black Market for Oil Blunts Trump’s India Tariffs
item.description: The extra levy meant to punish New Delhi for buying cheap Russian crude isn’t going as expected.
item.dc:creator: Carol Ryan

item.title: U.S. Tariffs on India Skirt Its Biggest Buyer of Russian Oil
item.description: Reliance Industries accounts for about a third of the Russian oil India imports.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: India Braces for the Pain of Trump’s Stiff Tariffs
item.description: Duties that just took effect will hit billions of dollars of trade and hurt Indian sectors ranging from textiles to farming.
item.dc:creator: Tripti Lahiri

item.title: Decades After Genocide, Rwanda Emerges as Aggressive Regional Power
item.description: The tiny country has evolved from an object of sympathy into a controversial and feared powerhouse.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Phillips

item.title: Why India Can’t Afford to Jettison Its Relationship With Russia
item.description: Despite the threat of U.S. tariffs, New Delhi is resisting pressure to cut longtime ties with Moscow that have brought economic and geopolitical benefits.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Grove

item.title: The Best Travel Shoes to Make Every Trip Lighter and Easier
item.description: No matter the destination, these shoes will get you there.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Selinger

item.title: The Best Laptop Backpacks, According to CEOs, Pilots and Stylists
item.description: From commuting to long-haul flights, these are the bags avid travelers rely on for their trips.
item.dc:creator: Sal Vaglica

item.title: Best of Buy Side Awards 2025: Travel
item.description: Tried and tested by our expert travel writers and editors, these Buy Side best product award-winning luggage picks will ensure your trip gets off to a great start.
item.dc:creator: Nick Guy

item.title: Families Battle Tech Giants as Australia Pushes for an Under-16 Social-Media Ban
item.description: The proposal marks the latest effort by political leaders worldwide to regulate children’s use of platforms, amid concerns that it is harming their mental health.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: ‘We’ve Got to Kill’: Inside New Zealand’s Mission to Wipe Out Predators
item.description: Scientists debate whether a multibillion-dollar plan to eliminate invasive animals by 2050 is feasible.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney

item.title: France’s Macron Tries to Quell New Caledonia Riots With Globe-Crossing Trip
item.description: The French leader said he is open to suspending a voting-rights bill that sparked the riots once order is restored on the archipelago and talks resume between rival factions.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Meichtry

item.title: France Rushes Reinforcements to Riot-Stricken New Caledonia
item.description: Unrest in the overseas territory could derail President Emmanuel Macron’s efforts to restore French influence in the Indo-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Rhiannon Hoyle

item.title: Australia to Boost Defense Spending Amid U.S.-China Tensions
item.description: Australia is boosting its defense budget and rethinking its defense plans as strategic competition between the U.S. and China heats up in the Indo-Pacific region.
item.dc:creator: Mike Cherney
